Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Evolution of hyperaccumulation in wild Helianthus: a phylogenetically explicit assessment of evolutionary history and adaptive hypotheses
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over 500 species of flowering plants are metal hyperaccumulators, meaning they possess the ability to take up extremely high concentrations of normally toxic metals into their shoot tissues. This natural ability may be harnessed for useful technological applications, including phytoremediation (the use of plants for environmental cleanup of polluted areas) as well as biofortification (the enrichment of crops with key nutrients like iron). The broad objective of the proposed research is to understand how the development of metal hyperaccumulation ability depends on metal tolerance, and how hyperaccumulation ability may benefit wild plants. Proposed benefits of hyperaccumulation to plants have included reduced herbivory and disease, improved drought tolerance, and reduced competition. This research will test these proposed benefits using the genus Helianthus (the sunflowers), a group of diverse species found in habitats across North America. Sunflowers are known to many for the agriculturally and horticulturally important crop species Helianthus annuus, which is itself a known hyperaccumulator of at least five different heavy metals. In addition to improving our understanding of plant ecology, this research will provide direct insights into hyperaccumulator physiology for the improved breeding and use of sunflower in technological applications.

The evolutionary interactions of metal tolerance and metal hyperaccumulation will be assessed using 35 wild Helianthus species, through a manipulative greenhouse study generating a soil nickel gradient consisting of ten separate treatment levels, in which the evolution of tolerance and hyperaccumulation are parsed apart as separate and distinct traits. The putative costs and benefits of hyperaccumulation will be examined in greenhouse experiments which will quantify fitness-related costs while simultaneously evaluating five leading adaptive hypotheses. A phylogenetically explicit approach to the study of metal hyperaccumulation evolution can dramatically improve the understanding of the ecological and evolutionary context of metal hyperaccumulation. More broadly, this research will promote further development of the newly emerging field of evolutionary toxicology and will implement novel phylogenetic comparative methods for assessing environmentally responsive traits, allowing for an improved range of tools to address existing and emerging environmental concerns.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metal hyperaccumulation (the uptake of extremely high concentrations of normally toxic metals into plant shoots) occurs in over 500 plants distributed across the angiosperm phylogeny. The genetics, physiology, and ecology of hyperaccumulation and metal tolerance have been heavily studied in only a few isolated taxa, and a thorough understanding of the evolutionary dynamics of plant metal hyperaccumulation is lacking. This project, through multiple greenhouse studies involving metal-amended soils, wild sunflowers, and cultivated sunflowers, assessed hyperaccumulation and metal tolerance across the genus Helianthus. Using phylogenetic comparative methods, this project revealed that tolerance and hyperaccumulation likely evolved independently from one another throughout the diversification of this group of species. Several new hyperaccumulators were identified within the genus, including species that concentrate nickel, zinc, cadmium, and copper either individually or in combination. A negative correlation between tolerance and hyperaccumulation was observed among species, which suggests the presence of an evolutionary tradeoff between these two capacities. In addition, the capacity for multiple metal hyperaccumulation was demonstrated to be an ancestral trait in the wild progenitor of crop sunflower and its close relatives, indicating that the presence of hyperaccumulation capacity in cultivated lines is unlikely to be an artifact of domestication.

One primary hypothesis for the repeated evolution of hyperaccumulation posits that the presence of high concentrations of toxic metals in shoot tissue deters herbivores, providing an evolutionary advantage by protecting tissues. This ‘elemental defense hypothesis’ was not generally supported in Helianthus. When caterpillars of the painted lady butterfly (Vanessa cardui) were given a choice between leaves of sunflower plants grown in non-metal-amended soils versus sunflower plants grown in amended soils, results varied by metal and by species. Although some species exhibited modest reductions in herbivory, others exhibited elevated herbivory when grown in metal-amended soils. Poor support for the elemental defense hypothesis suggests that other mechanisms may explain the evolution of metal hyperaccumulation, including accidental uptake by plants with strong nutrient uptake capacity.

The results of this research provide novel insights into the evolution of metal hyperaccumulation and tolerance in plants, and also into the evolution of phenotypically plastic traits in general (i.e., dose-response curves for soil metals). A thorough understanding of the dynamics of metal tolerance and hyperaccumulation is vital for improving technological applications of plant metal uptake, including mineral fortification of crop plants and phytoremediation of contaminated soils.
